clusters.name: Community Attraction and Onboarding
clusters.narrative: Potential contributors discover the project through reputation signals and community outreach. They evaluate whether to join based on perceived fit and available learning resources. New members enter through legitimate peripheral participation, accessing documentation and initial guidance. As they join, they bring diverse perspectives that can enhance problem-solving capacity. The onboarding process filters and prepares individuals for meaningful participation.
clusters.inputs: External talent pool, project reputation signals, community outreach efforts, documentation quality
clusters.outputs: New contributor candidates, diversity of perspectives, initial skill assessments, community growth signals

clusters.name: Knowledge Development and Skill Building
clusters.narrative: Contributors progress through structured learning pathways that combine explicit knowledge transfer through documentation with implicit knowledge sharing via mentorship. The SECI knowledge spiral operates as contributors socialize, externalize, combine, and internalize knowledge. Skill development occurs through legitimate peripheral participation, moving contributors from periphery to core. Transactive memory systems develop where contributors know who knows what, creating collective expertise. As skills grow, contributors gain self-efficacy and clearer career pathways.
clusters.inputs: New contributor candidates, mentorship capacity, documentation resources, learning opportunities
clusters.outputs: Skilled contributors, knowledge artifacts, mentorship capacity growth, career progression readiness

clusters.name: Contribution and Code Development
clusters.narrative: Skilled contributors engage with open issues and create pull requests to address project needs. The contribution process involves technical work, peer review, and integration of feedback. Task-technology fit influences how effectively contributors can address issues. Social capital develops as contributors build networks and bridge structural holes between different project areas. Quality signals emerge through code review and integration processes, affecting both individual reputation and project quality.
clusters.inputs: Skilled contributors, open issues, technical requirements, review capacity
clusters.outputs: Code contributions, pull request activity, technical debt changes, contributor reputation signals

clusters.name: Community Health and Retention
clusters.narrative: The community maintains health through balancing job demands with available resources, preventing burnout while sustaining engagement. Organizational routines stabilize through repeated interactions, but remain adaptable to changing conditions. Social capital accumulates through sustained relationships and trust-building activities. Retention mechanisms include recognition, career progression opportunities, and positive community culture. When demands exceed resources, turnover increases, creating knowledge loss that must be addressed through knowledge preservation.
clusters.inputs: Engaged contributors, community demands, recognition signals, resource availability
clusters.outputs: Retained core developers, community culture strength, knowledge preservation, turnover signals

clusters.name: Product Evolution and User Adoption
clusters.narrative: Code contributions integrate into the evolving codebase, creating new features and addressing user needs. Software quality and feature richness influence project reputation and user adoption rates. The innovation diffusion process spreads through user networks as early adopters influence later adopters. User feedback creates new issues and feature requests, driving further development. As the product evolves, it must maintain fit with user tasks and technological capabilities.
clusters.inputs: Integrated code contributions, user feedback, technological trends, market signals
clusters.outputs: Evolving software product, user adoption growth, reputation changes, new requirement signals

clusters.name: Reputation and Ecosystem Growth
clusters.narrative: Project reputation builds through successful outcomes, community health signals, and external recognition. Reputation signals attract new contributors, users, and potential collaborators. The ecosystem grows through network effects as more participants create more value. Social capital and structural advantages create competitive positioning. Reputation decline can occur through quality issues, community problems, or technological obsolescence, creating balancing feedback to maintain standards.
clusters.inputs: Project success signals, community health indicators, external recognition, network growth
clusters.outputs: Enhanced project reputation, ecosystem expansion, attraction signals, competitive positioning

clustering_scheme.overall_narrative: The open source ecosystem flows through interconnected processes that create virtuous cycles of growth and development. Community Attraction and Onboarding brings new talent into the system [overlap: Process 1→2], feeding the Knowledge Development and Skill Building process where contributors gain capabilities. Skilled contributors then flow into Contribution and Code Development [overlap: Process 2→3], creating value through code contributions. The resulting product improvements feed Product Evolution and User Adoption [overlap: Process 3→5], which generates success signals that enhance Reputation and Ecosystem Growth [overlap: Process 5→6]. Strong reputation then feeds back to attract more talent [feedback loop: Process 6→1], completing the primary growth cycle. Simultaneously, Community Health and Retention [Process 4] provides stabilizing forces, receiving engaged contributors from skill building [connection: Process 2→4] and feeding retained expertise back into contribution activities [feedback: Process 4→3]. Knowledge flows bidirectionally throughout, with transactive memory systems and SECI processes connecting all stages. The system maintains adaptability through feedback mechanisms where product evolution signals influence contribution priorities [connection: Process 5→3] and community health indicators affect attraction strategies [connection: Process 4→1].

theories.name: Process-Based Enhancement
theories.rationale: Variables and connections generated from process narratives

variables.name: Potential Contributor Pool
variables.description: Individuals aware of and considering joining the project

variables.name: New Contributor Candidates
variables.description: Individuals who have completed initial evaluation and are ready for onboarding

variables.name: Project Discovery Rate
variables.description: Rate at which potential contributors discover the project

variables.name: Evaluation and Joining Rate
variables.description: Rate at which potential contributors evaluate and decide to join

variables.name: Perceived Project Fit
variables.description: Potential contributors' perception of alignment with project goals and values

variables.name: Learning Resource Availability
variables.description: Accessibility and quality of documentation and initial guidance

variables.name: Community Outreach Effectiveness
variables.description: Effectiveness of community outreach efforts in attracting talent

variables.name: Initial Skill Assessment Quality
variables.description: Quality of initial skill evaluation during onboarding

variables.name: Contributor Skill Level
variables.description: Accumulated skills and capabilities of contributors

variables.name: Knowledge Artifacts
variables.description: Documentation, guides, and other explicit knowledge resources

variables.name: Skill Development Rate
variables.description: Rate at which contributors gain new skills and capabilities

variables.name: Knowledge Creation Rate
variables.description: Rate at which new knowledge artifacts are created

variables.name: Mentorship Capacity
variables.description: Available mentorship resources and capability

variables.name: Learning Pathway Effectiveness
variables.description: Effectiveness of structured learning pathways

variables.name: SECI Knowledge Spiral Effectiveness
variables.description: Effectiveness of socialization, externalization, combination, internalization processes

variables.name: Transactive Memory System Strength
variables.description: Effectiveness of collective knowledge about who knows what

variables.name: Contributor Self-Efficacy
variables.description: Contributors' belief in their ability to succeed

variables.name: Pull Request Backlog
variables.description: Accumulated pull requests awaiting review and integration

variables.name: Technical Debt
variables.description: Accumulated technical debt requiring future rework

variables.name: Pull Request Creation Rate
variables.description: Rate at which new pull requests are created

variables.name: Code Integration Rate
variables.description: Rate at which pull requests are reviewed and integrated

variables.name: Technical Debt Accumulation Rate
variables.description: Rate at which technical debt accumulates

variables.name: Task-Technology Fit
variables.description: Alignment between contributor skills and technical requirements

variables.name: Review Capacity
variables.description: Available capacity for reviewing and integrating contributions

variables.name: Social Capital
variables.description: Networks, relationships, and trust among contributors

variables.name: Code Quality Signals
variables.description: Signals indicating quality of code contributions

variables.name: Community Engagement Level
variables.description: Overall level of contributor engagement and participation

variables.name: Organizational Routine Stability
variables.description: Stability and effectiveness of established community routines

variables.name: Engagement Building Rate

variables.name: Burnout Accumulation Rate
variables.description: Rate at which burnout and disengagement accumulate

variables.name: Job Demands vs Resources Balance
variables.description: Balance between community demands and available resources

variables.name: Recognition Effectiveness
variables.description: Effectiveness of recognition and reward systems

variables.name: Career Progression Opportunities
variables.description: Availability of clear career progression pathways

variables.name: Knowledge Preservation Effectiveness
variables.description: Effectiveness of preserving knowledge when contributors leave

variables.name: Software Feature Richness
variables.description: Accumulated features and capabilities of the software

variables.name: User Satisfaction Level
variables.description: Overall satisfaction level of user base

variables.name: Feature Integration Rate
variables.description: Rate at which new features are integrated into the software

variables.name: User Satisfaction Change Rate
variables.description: Rate at which user satisfaction changes

variables.name: Software Quality
variables.description: Overall quality and reliability of the software

variables.name: Task-Technology Fit for Users
variables.description: Alignment between software capabilities and user needs

variables.name: Innovation Diffusion Effectiveness
variables.description: Effectiveness of spreading adoption through user networks

variables.name: User Feedback Quality

variables.name: Competitive Positioning Strength

variables.description: Rate at which network effects accumulate

boundary_flows.description: External talent market and broader open source ecosystem
